p: The germline in sexually reproducing organisms is ‘immortal’ [27]. Only genetic changes that occur in the germline and their progenitor cells will be passed on to future generations. Primordial germ cells (PGCs) are the progenitors of egg and sperm ( Fig. 1) and emerge around the second to fourth week of fetal development when gastrulation occurs in humans [28], [29]. Once specified, primordial germ cells migrate to the genital ridges until the 10th week where they then divide further as gonocytes or oogonia in the male or female gonad, respectively.
